												My hopes were quite high because I enjoyed the first part of Warlock - MotA quite much but I have to say that this game just plays worse as its predecessor so I can’t recommend it and rather suggest to buy the first part or my favorite game of that sorts: Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes.My main problem is the “small worlds” concept and the balancing and randomness of the game. Also some dialogues/story elements feel like they have a target group of 12 years old – but perhaps it is just not my type of humor. Also there are many smaller bugs that could be fixed in no time but it looks like the devs don’t care.As for the game, you start with one city on a random world (from death to elven, everything seems to be possible but has a great impact on how it plays). So usually you start exploring it and searching for other suitable places to build more cities and get access to important special resources. But this world is so small that it doesn’t make sense to build a second city on it – at least you won’t find a perfect place and you most likely will interfere with your first city or build on the edge of the world and won’t have many tiles to your disposal. When I continued playing I saw that the AI is placing like 5 cities on such a plane which feels just wrong but seems to be necessary in that game. I love creating a network of megacities in such games and this is simply not possible here due to the small land sizes. There is a setting for world size but I already chose the 2nd highest and I’m not sure if this means more small worlds or bigger worlds. I saw like 7 worlds in my plays and only 1 of them was quite large and could host 3 cities easily so I don’t know how (un-)lucky I was.In order to progress you have to use a “bridge” to the next world of comparable size. But those bridges are usually not free of charge. You have to spend some money or mana on being able to pass through or simple have to rely on luck (the conditions you have to fulfill to be able to use it seem to be random). Furthermore there are monster lairs everywhere (like every 2-3 tiles). They are good to get some combat training for your units and get gold, mana or even unique bonuses or spells from looting them, but sometimes there are overpowered enemies in those lairs which you either have to move around or join all your forces to be able to kill them. So this either needs some turns/time or it blocks your progress all together. In Warlock 1 you had enough space to ignore those monsters for now but here you might just not be able to play on.Well the good thing about that worlds and bridges concept could be that you have some kind of progress and frontline you can push. But in reality it is just a huge pain in the… because of random monster spawns. So what is happening is that you are trying to loot/conquer the next world with your army and then some ridiculous strong monster just spawns close to one of your important cities and you need like at least 5 turns to push your army back to defeat that monster, probably even after it took your city. So you can either lose countless turns in just moving your units back and forward or you can reload a save game 10 turns earlier and not even start to move away and rather secure the area. Both just feels bad and after it happened the 3rd time in my ~6 hours game I stopped playing. There are really games that are just more fun than having to cope with random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t you can’t predict and throw your progress back for half an hour or so…Some examples of annoyances:Whenever you load a game you have to click through all active quests and confirm them again (most can’t be denied anyway)You still can build harbors and ships but there are no oceans in the game, only small ponds, making them totally useless. Really devs?? How lazy are you?There are many small graphic glitches like small lines in the hud (probably bad cut out graphics), flickering textures (rarely) or a just strange looking background layer of the worlds…When you have a unit selected and want to switch planes you send the unit to that plane (I guess it is a feature but when you have to reload because you just wasted your move it can be annoying)What some might like is that the game sets more focus on terraforming. Due to the small worlds this is more important than before and there are random terraforming events you might have to react to. The whole spell research is better and more important now. You could fully ignore magic in the first part of the game and now you also can learn global benefits like higher production or less unrest by learning certain spells. But I think that is the only improvement to the first game…So this not necessarily a bad game and I rarely don’t recommend a game but I got the feeling that they only switched to the “small worlds concept” because marketing needed something to distinguish it from the first part. The rest of the changes could have been an update or dlc for part 1…

												If you have played the original Warlock, consider this a sort-of expansion pack. It changes a few core mechanics (one of them being the city construction), but it plays largely the same, with a few new units, a new faction and more story-driven campaign option.If you haven't played the original, let's get to it!Warlock 2 is aturn-based strategy game where you build up your whimsical magical empire, build yourself some gentleman werewolves and go on to crush the opposition! It shares quite a few design elements with Civilisation V, though it differs in several points.Firstly, your research does not help you progress through eras, rather, it lets you unlock new spells! What is a great mage without a fireball, after all? You even get to worship gods and learn some of their spells, as well.Advanced units are unlocked through city improvements and have many varied abilities and attributes. Truly, the faction differences are the main strength of the game, each having its own distinct style and slightly different approach to gameplay.With loads of colour and dozens of different units, each with its own set of defining attributes, you've got a nice blend of tools to work with. IF you are a warmonger.That may be construed as the game's biggest flaw, as diplomacy has little place in the world of Warlock. The AI is bad at it and even with human players, you're quite incentivized to be at each other's throats constantly. After all, why be one of the greatest mages, when you could be the Greatest Mage?If you don't mind blasting the enemy with fireballs, though, and you don't fear bears (the neutral armies in the game are rather terrifying at times), Warlock II has all the enjoyment you need!

												Just finished this game on Casual level and thought to write a review.  The simple way to review this game is to say that that if you liked Warlock: Master of the Arcane, you will like this game as well.  If you didn't like the first part or haven't played it, but are looking for a turn-based strategy with lots of variety, challenging AI and reward for your strategic decisions, then this is not a game for you. As someone who really enjoyed the first game, I liked this one very much.I thought to go further and write the differences between this and original game, but other people already covered that and you can read it on internet.  I'll just add a few things that I thought were the worse than in the original, for those people that expect everything to be same or better.1. Even more than in the original game, the location of your initial capital can make big difference, from a very easy ride, to an impossible to finish.  Don't be shy restarting the game a few times until your capital is in good location.2. You can safely only control a certain number of cities (starts with 5, but increases as you research some traits to maximum of eleven - yes, like with spells, you can choose to research traits that help you manage your realm).  If you go over this number, people get unhappy which gives penalties and I believe can lead into some sort of riot - I've never got that far.  You can have unlimited number of specialist cities (those that only make gold, or are like a fortress, or temple cities to a deity that improve relations with that deity and produce some mana).  This is really a shame when you conquer some good cities (but still not better than those you already have) - you just have to destroy them, or wait for 10 turns for "plundered" status to disappear before you can convert them to a specialist city.3. When a building give you perks to use, it's only a limited number of uses.  For example, a smithy will give you only 5 armours, which means you can only give the perk to 5 units.  This is applicable to each smithy, so if you have 2 smithies, that's 10 units to give the perk to.  But with the limited number of cities, you don't want to build smithy in each one.  Not to mention buildings that require a few other buildings to be built before you can have them, like University, or buildings that need a resource tile to be built.  You will never be able to control all resources.  So you have to choose carefully which unit you will give a perk to.  Heroes are the obvious choice, but even with them, a healer lord that stays out of fights may not necessarily need all the armour upgrades.For the end, there are a few bugs (for example, mass heal spell doesn't heal all the units in the range), but not enough to make the game too frustrating.  I didn't have a single time that the game crushed during the play, so that's obviously a good thing.

While this game has many qualities that I like, there are many things about it I do not. I will skip the nonsense and go straight to the pros and cons.Pros:*There are many game settings you can choose from in the sandbox mode, which is great for giving you just the right amount of a challenge.*The game has a nice selection of characters to choose from. Each one very customizable, and many different races to choose as a starting city.*The variety of units and enemies are very expansive. I never felt like every other race was just a clone of another.*The game has a large amount of replayability. The above mentioned items, as well as completely random worlds and situations make each session unique.Cons:*For many users, this game encounters random crashes with no warnings or crash screen to explain what happened.*The AI is extremely annoying. Almost every single game I play, the opponents constantly bug me for non-aggression pacts and alliances every 2 or 3 turns. I got to one point in a game where I met all 8 of them, and every 2 or 3 turns, all 8 of them asked for an alliance. You almost have to declare war on them just to make them shut up. But then they just ask for peace every few turns. This does not change based on difficulty.*It is too easy to steamroll enemies. Honestly the most challenging parts of the game I have found to be exploring the other worlds with extremely hard wild monsters. Even on the max difficulty though, once you build up to it, you can just mow through every faction with little to no resistance. Their combat AI is no better than their diplomacy AI.Other than that though, the game really has some potential. If someone out there was good with code, and could mod it to have a decent AI, I would recommend this game in a heartbeat. Or if the developer ever desires to finish what could have been an amazing game. As it stands though, I do not recommend it. At least not at full price. Wait for a Steam sale, and if you are dying for some new 4x, give it a shot.

												TLDR: If you liked #1, this is an even better game. :-)After finishing my first campaign, I found it to be quite a bit of fun.My campaign of conquest was to return and overthrow the united one.What I'd expected before I got there, was a huge map at the end, much like the starting map in Warlock 1, through which I'd have to fight a campaign of attrition against a heavily entrenched enemy, with many cities.Imagine my surprise when I pop in and it's just another small world, with a few great mages now acting as just a few high level heros.Because of this, the ending was rather short and anti-climactic.Overall I found the spellbook to be a nice improvement over the previous, completely random one.I like being able to see what is available and go for a specific thing in the long run.This both reduced the time before I got useful spells and gave me a better feel of control of my guys magic.I was happy to see my favorite area of Summoning to be expanded both in basic spells and in divine ones.I was surprised you could now get dragon & elementals both as summons and city build units.The game was stable throughout and did not crash or freeze once, unlike Warlock 1, which would randomly just sort of get stuck during a great mage turn... which happened every fifth game, it seemed.The only bad thing about this which I can think of is that shadow bats are half of what pops up in the randomly generated lairs, which are generated at regular intervals; These units are WAY to powerful to be frequent popup units!

												At Release, I gave Warlock 2 a positive review. As a huge fan of the first Warlock, I loved the notion of a sequel, and the content additions and new campaign were very enjoyable. I do, however, have to take into consideration the mismanagement of the game after release. At launch, there were bugs. Some were fixed, but many still remain 18 months after release. Many of the bugs in this final build are still very game-breaking. While some of the modders in the community have addressed some of these, and in fact still push out content even to this day, the fact that developers could not be bothered to fix the game, while instead pushing new DLC, is troubling. If you come across this review and are on the fence about buying it, I have to recommend that you pass...
